title: Grades K-5: American Sign Language, Level I
subject: Languages Other Than English (2014-)

document.title: Texas Essential Knowledge and Skills for Languages Other Than English

9A351386BD2A4AADA3B200CBDB1EE83F.description: show evidence of becoming a lifelong learner by using ASL at the novice proficiency level for personal enrichment and/or career development.

E4FB77EC11F34039ADC5A6B0BC16C9BC.description: be aware of methods of technology to communicate with the Deaf/ASL community; and

16E5F36D4BF04B47B047F719D351D4D2.description: apply ASL at the novice proficiency level in or out of the school setting through involvement in cultural activities such as attending Deaf events;

C1E8288D4849441798D98394077EAC52.description: Communities. The student participates in the Deaf/ASL community by using ASL. The student is expected to:

E6AD5917613447E4B263E8BD5E7DB54B.description: demonstrate an understanding of how one language and culture can influence another.

1B8A9793A1F344E7BDD9B7FCC4C6C5E4.description: demonstrate an understanding of the nature of culture through comparisons of the student's own culture and the American Deaf culture; and

67B39D30BA9A437EB81CBC71B80EB1BF.description: demonstrate an understanding of the nature of language through comparisons of the student's own language and ASL;

A674A094A6E64E0FA6AD76DD47580A34.description: Comparisons. The student develops insight into the nature of language and culture by comparing the student's own language and culture to ASL and American Deaf culture. The student is expected to:

2D2D37762E05458EAA8020B9E65B5421.description: use ASL to obtain, reinforce, or expand knowledge of other subject areas.

C790DB0E025D4A168E689D56115D79BC.description: use resources and digital technology to gain access to information about ASL and Deaf culture; and

A299FB955C4946C5BA21D0CF15D89D2E.description: Connections. The student uses ASL to make connections with other subject areas and to acquire information. The student is expected to:

C1A5E8B758194655AF1DF90B7226DF9E.description: demonstrate an understanding of Deaf history and how it applies to the perspectives of American Deaf culture.

CF941AA3F8B7412F80A25C9188BCDC00.description: show evidence of appreciation of the contributions by the Deaf and how they are applied to the perspectives of American Deaf culture such as historical, geographical, political, artistic, and scientific avenues; and

06B2FF9D3C244F99929080890135A7E0.description: show evidence of appreciation of ASL literature created by the Deaf and how it applies to the perspectives of American Deaf culture;

5BE8AAF9C55A421D96C80E4704004A2C.description: recognize and use Deaf cultural norms to demonstrate an understanding of the perspectives of American Deaf culture;

DC3217F6D1E442BC8503D71A38E3FA81.description: Cultures. The student gains knowledge and understanding of American Deaf culture. The student is expected to:

A5D8081091914A4299D83A57A2C9D416.description: be exposed to and experience ASL literature such as handshape stories that follows traditional cultural features.

D86590682E004823A040F8DD9178ACFE.description: demonstrate appropriate usage of ASL phonology, morphology, syntax, semantics, and pragmatics; and

5DE2DC223F394F4CA166E098C836565B.description: convey information in ASL using familiar words, concepts, classifiers, phrases, and sentences to others without voice;

3B0905DF348B45B793D56C01F42411BC.description: demonstrate an understanding of basic ASL such as simple stories, everyday commands, and brief instructions when dealing with familiar topics;

49AB4061ADCD4F19940D4698E831221B.description: engage in a variety of ASL exchanges of learned material to socialize and to provide and obtain information;

44FE1B5F9E6140BF934FF674A94910A5.description: Communication. The student communicates in ASL using expressive and receptive communication skills without voice. The student is expected to:
